sentence: Concerns of a stock market crash have been put at ease during the past week, but still, investors can't deny the market's volatility, or the fact that it could crash at any moment.
If a crash occurs, Fool contributing analysts have their own picks for stocks that will remain safe and may even yield large returns.
Andr√©s Cardenal : No company is 100% immune to economic headwinds or bear markets; however , Procter & Gamble is probably as close as you can get.
The company owns a rock-solid competitive position in several consumer-staples categories, Procter & Gamble sells products that everyone needs on a regular basis, as opposed to discretionary items.
This advantage provides reliability and predictability in the company's cash flows through good and bad times.

Procter & Gamble owns an enormously valuable portfolio of 23 brands generating over $1 billion in global sales and 14 additional brands making between $500 million and $1 billion per year, many of which are on their way to becoming billion-dollar brands on their own in the middle term.

The company is putting quality over quantity; Procter & Gamble is selling many of its underperforming brands to concentrate on its most promising names with superior profitability and potential for growth.
In fact, Procter & Gamble has recently announced that it plans to spin off its Duracell personal-batteries business.
Management believes Procter & Gamble is on track to not only achieve but also exceed its goal of reducing costs by $10 billion through various productivity initiatives.
This global consumer powerhouse isn't resting on its laurels.
The company is focused on efficiency and optimization to maximize value for shareholders.

With an amazing track record of 124 consecutive years of paying uninterrupted dividends, and 58 years in a row increasing those payments, Procter & Gamble is one of the most renowned and respected dividend stocks in the market.

The dividend yield is quite attractive at 3.1%, which should provide some downside protection in a bear market

Anders Bylund : When NYU Finance professor Aswath Damodaran wrote his seminal work on risk management, titled "Strategic Risk Taking," he needed a good example of a firm that generally doesn't rise and fall with the overall economy.
He picked Walt Disney for this exercise, and for good reason.
Damodaran provided solid proof that Disney's business and overall value don't follow the overall economy's health at all -- but Disney investors should pay attention to inflation.
And higher inflation is better this time.
To follow along at home with Damodaran's proof that Disney often zigs when the economy zags, you can access the book for free at Damodaran's website nowadays.
The Disney talk starts on Page 6 of Chapter 10.
I'll provide some updated figures, since the book is starting to show its age.
Damodaran shows an extremely weak correlation between gross domestic product changes and Disney's enterprise value, which in turn proves that Disney's overall value isn't tied to economic cycles.
Since then, GDP has increased by 40% while Disney's enterprise value nearly tripled, rising 187% in nearly 10 years.
This value has often moved crosswise to the GDP trend.
I think it's still fair to say that Disney's value is separate from whatever the economy and markets might be up to.
On the other hand, Damodaran proved that Disney's operating income tends to follow changes in inflation rates.
High inflation helps Disney's profits, while low inflation hurts them.
Disney's operating income has indeed soared over the past decade, while inflation rates have hovered above historical averages.
Long story short, Disney tends to truck along whether or not the economy as a whole is healthy.
The company likes foreign currency, so high inflation and a weak dollar actually help.
There are many reasons to own Disney shares, as I do.
Among them, you'll find that this stock works like a hedge against the scariest economic indicators out there.
Brian Nichols : No matter how bad the market gets or what the economy throws our way, we all have to eat.
Grocery is an industry that'll always stay in high demand, and Kroger is one of the best companies in the industry.
However, Kroger is not just any grocery company.
It's one of the largest, with $104 billion in trailing-12-month revenue, and it's also the fastest growing.
During Kroger's last quarter, its same-store sales rose nearly 5%.
Kroger has achieved this growth by expanding the size of its stores with more retail merchandise, such as home goods and clothes.
While Kroger's high-single-digit growth rate is expected to continue for the foreseeable future, it has also made a number of key investments to grow larger in the long term.
For one, Kroger's organic brand Simple Truth, which launched in 2012, is already expected to create $1 billion in sales this year.
In an $80 billion market that's expected to grow at a 14% compound annual rate through 2018, organic food could be a significant growth driver for Kroger.
Furthermore, Kroger has made a push into e-commerce with the acquisitions of Vitacost.com and Harris Teeter.
Vitacost.com is an online seller of vitamins and organic foods.
Harris Teeter is a physical grocery retailer that has a successful service allowing customers to buy online and pick up in the store.
Online grocery sales are currently just $27 billion, but BMC expects the market to be worth $123 billion by 2023, meaning this is another potential growth driver for Kroger.
While Kroger's 1.4% dividend yield isn't as high as many investors prefer in the event of a down market, Kroger has increased its quarterly dividend by nearly 95% over the past five years.
At 14.8 times forward earnings, Kroger is slightly cheaper than the S&P 500 at 16 times next year's expected earnings.
Combined with Kroger's current growth, its future opportunities in organic and online grocery, and its valuation, Kroger's stock is unlikely to fall too much in the event of a stock market crash.
In fact, it might even continue to trade higher.

These top dividend stocks are secure for decades

The smartest investors know that dividend stocks simply crush their non-dividend paying counterparts over the long term.
That's beyond dispute.
They also know that a well-constructed dividend portfolio creates wealth steadily, while still allowing you to sleep like a baby.
Knowing how valuable such a portfolio might be, our top analysts put together a report on a group of high-yielding stocks that should be in any income investor's portfolio.
To see our free report on these stocks, just click here .
